questions.text: You are doing a presentation on Vibrio. You come across a species of Vibrio that shows 'Kanagawa' phenomena and grows in a halophilic medium of 8% salt solution. Which of the following Vibrio species are you most likely referring to?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vibrio parahaemolyticus exhibits the Kanagawa phenomenon and thrives in halophilic environments, often requiring up to 8% NaCl for optimal growth.

  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus is a halophilic, gram-negative curved bacillus commonly found in marine environments and is associated with the consumption of undercooked seafood.
  • It causes acute gastroenteritis.
  • The Kanagawa phenomenon refers to its ability to lyse human red blood cells on Wagatsuma agar due to the production of thermostable direct hemolysin (TDH), which is considered a marker of virulence.
  • This organism is halophilic, meaning it requires elevated salt concentrations (up to 8% NaCl) for growth, which distinguishes it from other Vibrio species.
  • Its colonies demonstrate beta-hemolysis on high-salt mannitol media (Wagatsuma agar), which is specifically designed to detect the Kanagawa phenomenon.

Explanation of other options:

Vibrio cholerae (Option A): Non-halophilic and grows best in standard conditions; does not demonstrate the Kanagawa phenomenon. It produces cholera toxin and causes profuse watery diarrhea.

Vibrio vulnificus (Option C): Also halophilic but associated more with wound infections and septicemia, especially in immunocompromised individuals. It does not exhibit the Kanagawa phenomenon.

Vibrio alginolyticus (Option D): Requires salt for growth and is found in marine environments, but is rarely pathogenic and does not demonstrate the Kanagawa phenomenon.

questions.text: Raju, a 5-year-old boy, presents to the OPD with complaints of abdominal cramps associated with classical rice water diarrhea. On examination, his skin pinch test went back slowly. His vitals were as follows: temperature - 100.2°C, Pulse 120 bpm, RR- 32/min. Upon eliciting further history, it turns out his neighbours, who used the same well as his family, had also developed similar complaints. What is the drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis for his family members?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Doxycycline is the drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis of cholera in adults and close contacts in outbreak settings.

  • The child's symptoms-rice water diarrhea, rapid dehydration (evident by skin turgor), and a local cluster of similar cases using a common water source-are classic for cholera, caused by Vibrio cholerae.
  • During cholera outbreaks, chemoprophylaxis may be considered for household contacts of infected individuals, especially when the risk of transmission is high.
  • Doxycycline, a tetracycline derivative, is the first-line agent for prophylaxis in adults, typically given as a single 300 mg dose.
  • It is effective in eradicating carriage and reducing transmission.
  • Though doxycycline is generally avoided in children under 8 due to concerns of dental staining, for prophylaxis in adults, it remains the preferred drug.
  • For younger children or pregnant contacts, erythromycin or azithromycin may be considered as alternatives.

Explanation of other options:

Ciprofloxacin (Option A): Effective against many gram-negative organisms but not preferred for cholera chemoprophylaxis, due to increasing resistance and lesser efficacy in mass prophylaxis programs.

Ceftriaxone (Option B): A broad-spectrum cephalosporin; used in severe systemic infections, but not indicated for prophylaxis or treatment of cholera.

Azithromycin (Option C): Can be used in the treatment of cholera, especially in pregnant women or children, but not the first choice for chemoprophylaxis in adult contacts.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with epigastric pain, bloating, and occasional nausea. He has a history of frequent use of NSAIDs for chronic pain. On further investigation, a urease breath test is positive. What is the type of flagella possessed by the organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Helicobacter pylori possesses lophotrichous flagella, which help in its motility through the gastric mucosa.

  • The positive urease breath test and NSAID use in a patient with epigastric pain and dyspepsia strongly point toward Helicobacter pylori infection-a gram-negative, spiral-shaped bacillus known for colonizing the gastric mucosa.
  • pylori is characterized by having 4-6 sheathed flagella at one pole, i.e., lophotrichous flagella, which are essential for motility in the viscous gastric mucus layer.
  • This motility, combined with urease production, allows it to neutralize stomach acid and survive in the acidic environment.

Other types of flagella:

Explanation of other options:

Atrichous (Option A): Refers to bacteria that lack flagella entirely-H. pylori is not atrichous.

Monotrichous (Option C): Bacteria with a single flagellum, such as Vibrio cholerae, and Helicobacter pylori have multiple flagella at one pole, not just one.

Peritrichous (Option D): Flagella distributed all over the surface, seen in E. coli and Proteus; H. pylori has a polar (lophotrichous) arrangement.

questions.text:
You are studying the biochemical reactions of bacteria. You come across the following test where a suspension of the bacteria, along with bile salts, gives a string-like formation. Which of the following biochemical reactions will this bacterium show?

i. Cholera red reaction
ii. Kanagawa phenomena
iii. Black colonies on Tinsdale media
iv. Yellow colonies on TCBS agar
v. School of fish appearance on wet mount
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A positive string test is characteristic of Vibrio cholerae, which also shows a cholera red reaction and forms yellow colonies on TCBS agar.

  • The string test involves suspending bacterial colonies in sodium deoxycholate (a bile salt).
  • If the bacteria lyse due to bile, their DNA is released, forming a mucoid string when touched with a loop.
  • This is positive in Vibrio cholerae.
  • Vibrio cholerae also gives:
    • Cholera red reaction: when peptone water culture of V. cholerae is treated with sulfuric acid and nitrite, it produces a red color due to the formation of nitrosoindole.
    • Yellow colonies on TCBS (Thiosulfate Citrate Bile Salts Sucrose) agar: due to sucrose fermentation and acid production, turning the bromothymol blue indicator yellow.

Kanagawa phenomenon: Seen in Vibrio parahaemolyticus, not V. cholerae; associated with hemolysis on Wagatsuma agar.

Black colonies on Tinsdale media: Seen with Corynebacterium diphtheriae, due to H2S production and tellurite reduction, not seen in Vibrio.

School of fish appearance on wet mount: Classic of Haemophilus ducreyi, not related to Vibrio cholerae.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy came to the Pediatric OPD with complaints of low-grade fever, cough, and vomiting. His vitals are normal, and growth is appropriate for his age. On examination, the boy coughs 10 times in a row with a typical sound at the end. His parents do not believe in getting him vaccinated, stating that vaccines are for weak people and that their son is the strongest person. Which of the following media is used to isolate the given bacteria?
i. PPLO agar
ii. Bordet-Gengou agar
iii. PLET media
iv. Regan Lowe media
v. Pike's media
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bordetella pertussis is isolated using Bordet-Gengou or Regan-Lowe media

  • The clinical features: paroxysmal coughing fits, whooping, post-tussive vomiting, and lack of vaccination, are classic for pertussis, caused by Bordetella pertussis.
  • The most commonly used media for the isolation of Bordetella pertussis are:
    • Bordet-Gengou agar: Contains potato extract, glycerol, and blood; selective with antibiotics.
    • Regan-Lowe medium: A charcoal-blood agar with cephalexin; preferred due to better preservation of viability during transport and culture.
  • These media support the growth of B. pertussis, which is otherwise fastidious and difficult to culture.

PPLO agar: Used for Mycoplasma pneumoniae, not Bordetella pertussis.

PLET media: Used for Bacillus anthracis (anthrax), not for pertussis.

Pike's media: A transport medium for Streptococcus pyogenes, not Bordetella pertussis.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male presents with fever, dry cough, dyspnea, and diarrhea for 3 days. His temperature is 102.3°F, and BP is 90/66 mmHg. On examination, bilateral crepitants are noted. Lab results show:
Hb: 13.3 g%
WBC: 13,000/cu mm
Platelets: 2,00,000/cumm
Serum Na+: 130 mEq/L
Serum K+: 4.2 mEq/L
He works at a dairy unit, and neighbors sharing a central AC unit developed similar symptoms. Which laboratory method is most useful to identify the organism causing this disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Legionella pneumophila, the causative agent of Legionnaires' disease, is best isolated on Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract (BCYE) agar.

  • The patient's presentation-pneumonia with systemic symptoms, diarrhea, hyponatremia, and exposure to air-conditioning systems-is classic for Legionnaires' disease, caused by Legionella pneumophila.
  • This aerobic, gram-negative bacillus does not grow on ordinary media and requires L-cysteine and iron for growth.
  • The selective medium used for its isolation is BCYE (Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract) agar, which contains:
    • Yeast extract (source of nutrients)
    • Activated charcoal (neutralizes toxic compounds)
    • L-cysteine and ferric pyrophosphate (essential for growth)
  • BCYE agar is the gold standard for culture-based diagnosis of Legionella species.

Explanation of other options:

PLET media (Option B): Used for Bacillus anthracis, not Legionella.

Standard Agglutination Test (Option C): Used for Brucella species diagnosis, irrelevant in this context.

Urea Breath Test (Option D): Used for the detection of Helicobacter pylori, not Legionella.

questions.text: A 17-year-old patient presented with weakness and numbness in both lower limbs. He is unable to move his legs, has fasciculations, and absent DTRs (Deep Tendon Reflexes). His temperature is 98.4° F, BP is 112/70. On asking about history, the patient says, "I ate undercooked food 4 days ago, but I frequently do that and I am usually fine. However, 2 days ago, I had blood in my stool, and I panicked. Will I be okay, doctor?" The doctor puts a peripheral demyelinating disease in his differential. Which microbiological organism is most likely associated with this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Campylobacter jejuni infection is strongly associated with Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS), a peripheral demyelinating disease.

  • This patient has signs of acute flaccid paralysis with areflexia and recent bloody diarrhea, which is suggestive of Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS)-a post-infectious immune-mediated demyelinating polyneuropathy.
  • The most commonly associated organism with GBS is Campylobacter jejuni.
  • The bacterium often causes bloody diarrhea after ingestion of undercooked poultry or contaminated food and water.
  • The pathogenesis involves molecular mimicry between the lipooligosaccharides (LOS) of C. jejuni and gangliosides on peripheral nerves, leading to autoimmune attack on myelin or axon, resulting in ascending paralysis and areflexia.

Explanation of other options:

pylori (Option A): Associated with gastritis, peptic ulcers, and MALT lymphoma, not GBS or demyelinating neuropathies.

Zika virus (Option B): Has been occasionally linked with GBS, but it is a much rarer association compared to C. jejuni.

HIV (Option C): Can cause neuropathy, but it is not the most common infectious trigger for GBS, especially in acute post-diarrheal cases.

questions.text: A patient with HIV presents to the dermatology OPD with the following findings. The patient also complains of Fever, chills, malaise, night sweats, anorexia, and weight loss. Skin biopsy shows capillary proliferation and neutrophilic inflammation. Which of the following bacteria is implicated in this disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bartonella quintana causes bacillary angiomatosis in immunocompromised patients, especially those with HIV.

  • The presentation of vascular skin lesions, systemic symptoms (fever, malaise, weight loss), and HIV positivity is highly suggestive of bacillary angiomatosis-a vascular proliferative disease seen in immunocompromised individuals, especially those with AIDS.
  • The condition is caused by Bartonella henselae or Bartonella quintana.
  • Among them, Bartonella quintana is the classic agent associated with bacillary angiomatosis, especially in homeless or immunocompromised populations.
  • It leads to capillary proliferation with associated neutrophilic infiltrates, as described in the biopsy.
  • The infection is angiogenic, producing blood-filled vascular lesions that can mimic Kaposi sarcoma clinically, but biopsy reveals bacterial aggregates and inflammatory changes.

Explanation of other options:

Coxiella burnetii (Option B): Causes Q fever-a zoonotic systemic illness; not associated with cutaneous vascular proliferative lesions.

Campylobacter (Option C): Associated with gastroenteritis and Guillain-Barré Syndrome; no role in skin angiomatous lesions.

Vibrio vulnificus (Option D): Causes wound infections and sepsis, especially in those with liver disease; lesions are typically necrotic or hemorrhagic, not vascular proliferations.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the medicine OPD with complaints of epigastric pain and heartburn, typically after a meal. He has been a known smoker for 15 years. A urease breath test for this patient is positive. The following bacteria are cultured on Warthin-Starry silver stain. This bacterial colonization causes all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Helicobacter pylori causes gastric and duodenal ulcers and MALT lymphoma, but is not directly associated with GERD.

  • The patient has symptoms suggestive of peptic ulcer disease, with a positive urease breath test and Warthin-Starry silver stain identifying Helicobacter pylori-a gram-negative, spiral-shaped, urease-producing bacillus.
  • pylori is strongly linked to:
    • Gastric ulcers (Option B ruled out)
    • Duodenal ulcers (Option C ruled out)
    • Gastric adenocarcinoma
    • Mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma, a type of non-Hodgkin gastric lymphoma (Option D ruled out)
  • However, GERD (gastroesophageal reflux disease) is not caused by H. pylori infection.
  • Some studies suggest H. pylori may even have a protective effect against GERD by reducing gastric acid output, especially in cases of corpus-predominant gastritis.

questions.text: As shown in the Figure, a 7-year-old child presented to the pediatric OPD with a lesion and swelling, having a history of visiting a pet farm 1 week before. On examination, the lesion is painless. From the swelling, a smear was made and was positive under Warthin-Starry silver nitrate staining. Identify the disease and its causative agent in this patient.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bartonella henselae causes cat-scratch disease in immunocompetent children, typically following contact with cats or pet animals.

  • Cat-scratch disease (CSD) is caused by Bartonella henselae, a gram-negative bacillus that can be visualized using Warthin-Starry silver stain.
  • It is typically seen in children or young adults following scratches, bites, or contact with cats, especially kittens.
  • The clinical presentation usually involves:
    • A painless papule at the inoculation site
    • Followed by regional lymphadenopathy (which may be tender or painless)
    • Often preceded by exposure to cats or pet farms
  • This child's recent pet farm visit, painless lesion, and Warthin-Starry positivity are classic for Cat-scratch disease.

Explanation of other options:

Bacillary angiomatosis; B. henselae (Option B): Seen in immunocompromised (e.g., HIV) patients, presents with vascular skin lesions, not isolated lymphadenopathy.

Trench fever; B. quintana (Option C): Spread by body lice, causes relapsing fever, not lymphadenopathy following pet exposure.

Carrion's disease; B. bacilliformis (Option D): Endemic to Peru, causes Oroya fever and verruga peruana, unrelated to pet exposure or cat contact.

Explanation:

Bartonella quintana causes trench fever, classically presenting as relapsing fever occurring every 5 days, hence called "5-day fever".

  • Bartonella quintana is a gram-negative bacillus, transmitted via the human body louse (Pediculus humanus corporis).
  • It was first identified during World War I among soldiers, where it caused trench fever, a febrile illness characterized by:
    • Sudden onset of high fever, which repeats every 5 days
    • Associated symptoms: headache, bone pain (especially shins), and malaise
    • The fever pattern gives it the nickname "5-day fever."
    • Seen in homeless populations, poor hygiene, or crowded conditions

Explanation of other options:

100 days fever (Option A): Incorrect term; no such condition is named as 100 days fever. Possibly confused with 100-day cough, which refers to pertussis.

5th day disease (Option B): Not a recognized clinical term; possibly a distractor mimicking "5th disease" (erythema infectiosum).

6th disease (Option D): Refers to Roseola infantum caused by HHV-6, unrelated to Bartonella.

questions.text: A microbiologist was explaining about a biphasic disease, inclusive of an initial phase of carrion's disease and a late cutaneous vascular phase of verruga peruana. Which causative agent was the microbiologist talking about?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bartonella bacilliformis causes Carrion's disease, a biphasic illness with an acute febrile hemolytic phase followed by chronic cutaneous angioproliferative lesions called verruga peruana.

  • Carrion's disease, also known as Oroya fever, is caused by Bartonella bacilliformis, a gram-negative bacterium endemic to Peru and Ecuador, transmitted by the sandfly (Lutzomyia).
  • It is presented in two phases:
    • Acute Phase (Oroya fever)
      • High-grade fever, chills
      • Severe hemolytic anemia and vasoproliferative endothelial damage
      • High mortality if untreated
    • Chronic Phase (Verruga peruana)
      • Weeks to months later
      • Angioproliferative skin lesions resembling hemangiomas
      • Painless, wart-like nodules on skin, face, and limbs
  • This biphasic nature is characteristic and pathognomonic for B. bacilliformis.

Explanation of other options:

henselae (Option A): Causes Cat-scratch disease and Bacillary angiomatosis, not associated with a biphasic illness or verruga peruana.

quintana (Option B): Responsible for Trench fever and sometimes bacillary angiomatosis in immunocompromised hosts; no biphasic cutaneous disease.

B. pseudomallei (Option D): Causes melioidosis, a potentially fatal bacterial infection found in Southeast Asia and Northern Australia, not a Bartonella species.

choices.text: Grows on charcoal yeast extract medium with iron and cysteine

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with fever, cough, and diarrhea. The patient has a history of recent travel to a hotel with an indoor pool. Chest X-ray shows bilateral infiltrates, and urinary antigen testing is positive. Which of the following media is most suitable for growing the causative organism in the laboratory?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Legionella pneumophila, the causative agent of Legionnaires' disease, grows best on charcoal yeast extract agar supplemented with iron and cysteine.

  • This patient presents with atypical pneumonia associated with recent travel, exposure to water systems (like indoor pools or AC systems), diarrhea, and a positive urinary antigen test, which strongly suggests Legionnaires' disease caused by Legionella pneumophila.
  • Legionella is a fastidious gram-negative bacillus that requires special culture conditions:
  • Charcoal yeast extract (CYE) agar is the standard culture medium.
  • It must be supplemented with:
    • L-cysteine: required for bacterial growth.
    • Iron salts (ferric pyrophosphate): enhance metabolism and replication.
  • These supplements are essential because Legionella cannot synthesize cysteine and needs iron for critical enzymatic processes.

Explanation of other options:

Grows on charcoal (Option A): Incomplete - charcoal is part of the medium but not sufficient alone; it absorbs toxic compounds.

Grows on iron (Option B): Legionella does require iron, but iron alone is not sufficient for growth.

Grows on cysteine (Option C): While cysteine is essential, it must be combined with iron and other components in the specific CYE medium for successful culture.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus presents with cellulitis after swimming at the beach. He also has a history of skin darkening over the years, and recent lab tests revealed elevated liver enzymes. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for his cellulitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vibrio vulnificus causes rapidly progressive cellulitis in patients with liver disease or diabetes after exposure to seawater or consumption of raw seafood.

  • Vibrio vulnificus is a halophilic gram-negative bacillus found in marine environments.
  • It can infect wounds exposed to seawater, especially in immunocompromised patients or those with chronic liver disease (such as hemochromatosis, indicated by skin darkening and elevated LFTs).
  • Key clinical features of Vibrio vulnificus infection include:
    • Cellulitis with hemorrhagic bullae
    • Sepsis and necrotizing fasciitis
    • Rapid progression in patients with diabetes, liver dysfunction, or iron overload
  • The patient’s history of beach exposure, diabetes, and liver disease makes V. vulnificus the most likely pathogen.
  • It is a medical emergency requiring aggressive antibiotic therapy (e.g., doxycycline + ceftazidime).

Explanation of other options:

Staphylococcus aureus (Option B): Common cause of cellulitis but not associated specifically with seawater exposure or liver disease.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Option C): Associated with hot tub folliculitis, not classic cellulitis post beach exposure in diabetics.

Streptococcus pyogenes (Option D): Can cause cellulitis and necrotizing fasciitis, but lacks the strong marine association and risk enhancement from liver disease.

choices.text: Urease positive, catalase positive, oxidase negative
Urease positive, catalase negative, oxidase positive
Urease positive, catalase positive, oxidase positive
Hemolysis on blood agar, coagulase positive

questions.text: A 48-year-old patient presents with recurrent heartburn, which improves after a 1-month trial of pantoprazole. Given the clinical improvement with proton pump inhibitor therapy, what are the positive biochemical reactions associated with the most likely causative organism in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Helicobacter pylori, the most likely cause of acid peptic symptoms, shows positive urease, catalase, and oxidase reactions.

  • The patient presents with chronic heartburn relieved by pantoprazole, a typical presentation of Helicobacter pylori-associated gastritis or peptic ulcer disease.
  • The improvement with PPI suggests acid-mediated pathology, most commonly caused by H. pylori, especially in middle-aged adults.
  • Biochemical characteristics of Helicobacter pylori:
    • Urease-positive: Converts urea to ammonia and CO2 to buffer gastric acid, aiding survival in acidic stomach.
    • Catalase-positive: Protects from oxidative damage.
    • Oxidase-positive: Indicates the presence of cytochrome c oxidase enzyme.
  • These features are diagnostic clues and are tested via rapid urease test, urea breath test, and biopsy.

Explanation of other options:

Urease positive, catalase positive, oxidase negative (Option A): Incorrect because H. pylori is oxidase-positive.

Urease positive, catalase negative, oxidase positive (Option B): Incorrect; H. pylori is catalase-positive, aiding oxidative stress defense.

Hemolysis on blood agar, coagulase positive (Option D): Describes Staphylococcus aureus, not related to acid-peptic disease or PPI response.
